body_content.explanation: correct:
examples: You got three answers right and two wrong.
I set the clock to the right time.
"Is that Ms Kramer?" "Yes, that's right."
Am I right in thinking (= is it true) that you will be at the conference?
You're right to be annoyed - you've been treated very badly.
You must put matters right (= make the situation better) by telling the truth.

body_content.explanation: If you are right about something or someone, you are correct in your judgment or statement about it, him, or her:
examples: You were right about Pete - he's a real troublemaker.

body_content.explanation: suitable or correct, or as it should be:
examples: He's the right person for the job.
I think you've made the right decision.
The temperature of the swimming pool was just right (= exactly as I wanted it).
That hat looks just right on you.
He thought the time was right to let his intentions be known.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to a person who is considered to be socially important or a place that such people go to:
examples: She knows all the right people.
He likes to be seen in the right clubs and restaurants.

body_content.explanation: in the correct position:
examples: The lid has to go on the right way round or it won't fit.

body_content.explanation: considered fair or morally acceptable by most people:
examples: I don't believe they should have put him in prison. It isn't right.
It's not right to criticize people behind their back.
It is only (= completely) right that men and women should be paid the same for doing the same work.

body_content.explanation: healthy, or working correctly:
examples: I haven't felt right since I ate that meal last night.
Something isn't quite right with the brakes on your bike.

body_content.explanation: used for emphasizing when something is bad:
examples: He's a right idiot.
His house is a right mess.

body_content.explanation: on or towards the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north:
examples: Most people write with their right hand.
He likes to sleep on the right side of the bed.

body_content.explanation: on or towards the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north:
examples: Turn/Go right (= take the road on the right) at the first traffic lights.

body_content.explanation: exactly or all the way:
examples: I've got a pimple right on the end of my nose.
They built a row of hotels right along the sea-front.

body_content.explanation: used for emphasis:
examples: The car ran right (= completely) out of fuel.
She walked right (= all the way) past me without noticing me.
I'll be right back/I'll be right with you (= I will return very soon).

body_content.explanation: immediately:
examples: I'll call them right away, because if I wait, I'll probably forget to do it.

body_content.explanation: at the present time:
examples: We're very busy right now.

body_content.explanation: immediately:
examples: You'd better leave right now.

body_content.explanation: used as part of the title of particular people, such as bishops and some members of Parliament:
examples: the Right Honourable Diane Abbott, MP

body_content.explanation: correctly:
examples: Why does he never do anything right?

body_content.explanation: If something goes right, it is successful or happens in a way that you hoped it would:
examples: Things haven't been going right for me these past few months.

body_content.explanation: the right side:
examples: English is written and read from left to right.
King's Avenue is the first right (= the first road on the right side).
In this photo, my wife is the woman standing on/to my right.
I took/made (informal hung) a right (= turned into the next road on the right side) after crossing the bridge.

body_content.explanation: political parties or people that have traditional opinions, and that believe in low taxes, property, and industry being privately owned, and less help for the poor:
examples: The right was/were in power after 1979.
He's a man of the far (= extreme) right.

body_content.explanation: what is considered to be morally good or acceptable:
examples: Your conscience should tell you the difference between right and wrong.

body_content.explanation: If you are in the right, what you are doing is morally or legally correct:
examples: You're definitely in the right - there's no doubt about that.

body_content.explanation: the fact that a person or animal can expect to be treated in a fair, morally acceptable, or legal way, or to have the things that are necessary for life:
examples: She campaigned for women's rights during the 1960s.
Everyone has a right to education.
She has no more right to a company car than I have (= she does not deserve one more than I do).
You're not my boss, so what right (= authority) do you have to tell me what to do?
You have every right (= you have a good reason) to complain.

body_content.explanation: If you are within your rights to do something, you are legally allowed to do it:
examples: I think I'm quite within my rights to demand a full refund.

body_content.explanation: legal controls over who is allowed to use a book or film:
examples: He has acquired the film rights to the book (= he is allowed to make a film of the book).

body_content.explanation: new shares in a particular company that have become available for people to buy who already own shares:
examples: The company made a rights issue of one new share for every four held.

body_content.explanation: to improve or correct something:
examples: The company needs over a million dollars to set its finances to rights.

body_content.explanation: used to express agreement with someone or to show that you have understood what someone has said:
examples: "Johnny, you climb up first." "Right."

body_content.explanation: said when you want to make a group of people notice you, especially so that you can start an activity:
examples: Right, everyone. Could you all stop talking, and then we'll begin.

body_content.explanation: said between parts of a story that you are telling, in order to make certain that people are paying attention and understanding:
examples: So there I was right, middle of the night, right, and this guy came up to me...

body_content.explanation: If you right a situation or a mistake, you make it better or correct it:
examples: It's a terrible situation and we should right it as soon as possible.

body_content.explanation: If a boat rights itself, it turns itself back to its correct position in the water:
examples: The canoe will right itself if it capsizes.
